Hrishikesh is a research scholar at the Department of Computer Science and Engineering, IIT Kanpur working under the supervision of Prof. Arnab Bhattacharya. His research interests include Natural Language Processing, Information Retrieval and Data Mining. He is particularly interested in Sanskrit and several other Indian languages. He likes building user-friendly GUIs and CLIs for academic and non-academic purposes.
He completed his B.Sc. (Hons.) in Mathematics and Computer Science (2010) and M.Sc. in Computer Science (2013) from Chennai Mathematical Institute.

summary: We present a web-based tool *Sangrahaka* for annotating entities and relationships from text corpora towards construction of a knowledge graph and subsequent querying using templatized natural language questions.  The application is language and corpus agnostic, but can be tuned for specific needs of a language or a corpus.  The application is freely available for download and installation.  Besides having a user-friendly interface, it is fast, supports customization, and is fault tolerant on both client and server side.  It outperforms other annotation tools in an objective evaluation metric.  The framework has been successfully used in two annotation tasks.
title: Sangrahaka: A Tool for Annotating and Querying Knowledge Graphs

content:
Annotation One of the ways of constructing a knowledge graph is through manual annotation. Languages whose state-of-the-art of NLP is not advanced enough for automatic construction often have to rely on the manual annotation. Benefits of annotation include the accuracy and reliability of data, construction of datasets which further help the research in the field of automatic construction of knowledge graphs, etc.
Sangrahaka Sangrahaka is a web-based tool for annotating entities and relationships from text corpora towards construction of a knowledge graph and subsequent querying using templatized natural language questions. It is a language and corpus agnostic tool. Salient features of the tool include an interface for annotation of entities and relationships, and an interface for querying using templatized natural language queries. The tool is also equipped with an administrators‚Äô interface for managing user access levels, uploading corpora and ontology creation. There are utility scripts for language-specific or corpus-specific needs. The tool can be deployed on the web for distributed annotation by multiple annotators. Besides having a user-friendly interface, it is fast, supports customization, and is fault-tolerant on both client and server side. No programming knowledge is expected from an annotator.
The tool has been used in real-world annotation tasks and has received generally positive reviews.

summary: Knowledge Graphs (KGs) are knowledge bases stored using a graph data structure. KGs find application in several fields such as Natural Langugage Processing, Information Retrieval, Databases for the purpose of storage, management and querying of real world data. In this project, we explore ways of constructing and querying KGs.
title: Knowledge Graphs

summary: Sanskrit (*Sa·πÉsk·πõta*) enjoys one of the largest and most varied literature in the whole world. Extracting the knowledge from it, however, is a challenging task due to multiple reasons including complexity of the language and paucity of standard natural language processing tools. In this paper, we target the problem of building knowledge graphs for particular types of relationships from Sa·πÉsk·πõta texts. We build a natural language question-answering system in Sa·πÉsk·πõta that uses the knowledge graph to answer factoid questions. We design a framework for the overall system and implement two separate instances of the system on human relationships from MahƒÅbhƒÅrata and RƒÅmƒÅya·πáa, and one instance on synonymous relationships from BhƒÅvaprakƒÅ≈õa Nigha·πá·π≠u, a technical text from ƒÄyurveda. We show that about 50% of the factoid questions can be answered correctly by the system. More importantly, we analyse the shortcomings of the system in detail for each step, and discuss the possible ways forward.
title: Framework for Question-Answering in Sanskrit through Automated Construction of Knowledge Graphs

content:
Sanskrit (Sa·πÉsk·πõta) enjoys one of the largest and most varied literature in the whole world. Extracting the knowledge from it, however, is a challenging task due to multiple reasons including complexity of the language and paucity of standard natural language processing tools.
In this project, we target the problem of building general purpose knowledge graphs (KG) from Sanskrit texts as well as building natural language question answering systems on top of the constructed KGs.
summary: Sanskrit is one of the most ancient and richest languages in the world. Its literature boasts of text spanning every facet of life and contains works on mathematics, arts, sciences, religion, philosophy, etc. Unfortunately, the large volume of such works and the relative lack of proficiency in the language have kept treasures in those text hidden from the common man. Unraveling information from these texts in a targeted and systematic manner can not only help in enhancing the knowledge systems but can also revive an interest in the language.
title: Sanskrit Question Answering
